scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Indian agent acknowledges Parker's letter of September 29 and regrets that some Tonawandas have refused to supply information Parker has been authorized to obtain. Angel instructs Parker to assure the chiefs the "proposed census has no concealed or hostile object" and applies to all Indians within the U.S. and its territories. Hopes to visit reservation soon to present in Council matter of importance concerning annuity money wasted by a preceding agent.

did.unittitle: ALS to George Jamerson and Thompson S. Harris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges letter of Sept. 5, stating Mr. Fellows has not yet paid their claim, but if matter is not settled soon he "will endeavor to force collection by a course of law." Regrets reports of sickness, but writes "it is a calamity which has been common to the whole country." There has been no appropriation from Congress to pay schedules. Asks them to let him know if they are receiving provisions from the government as stipulated and to send him names of the deceased.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Somewhat mutilated letter, giving news of the family and expressing hope his son will come East for a visit. Father believes mortality rate among those who went West is sufficient grounds for doing all he can "to save our lands from grasp of iniquitous Ogden Land Co." He has renounced liquor and adopted Christianity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typed copies of letter enclosing receipts amounting to $46.00 [?], covering E.S. Parker's expenses incurred on business in Washington on behalf of the Seneca Indians and of a petition from the Chiefs requesting that "the said Ely S. Parker may not lose the allowance he receives to assist him in his education" which was interrupted in March 1846 because they "have had and still continue to have great use for his services."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges his brother's letter received Oct. 2. Levi's dog is dead. Family is all together and well, and even though they lose their lands they will not go West to such "mean country."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photostat of letter requesting the Governor of New York "to enter proper complaints...under the Law of 1821" against White intruders. Indians have been informed by Wm. Brown of Philadelphia, who has had an interview with Wright, that State will protect them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One 8 p. issue, published in the main in Seneca, but partly in English, by the Mission Press, Cattaraugus Reservation, N.Y. Contains census returns for 1845-46 and "Results of Emigration." Latter article lists name of Thompson S. Harris and of other deceased members of the party who left for the West in May 1846.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Twenty-two pages of a diary with comments on New Year's Day calls on President Polk, Dolly Madison and others; paintings of Indians in the Capitol; Sunday sermons on Christianity; a fire at Jackson's Hall during a celebration in honor of Jackson's victory at New Orleans; funeral of Senator Pennybacker; meetings with sympathetic senators; Ely's efforts on behalf of the Tonawanda Indians' land case, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Levi has received a letter from Benjamin Williams informing him that two thirds of the Indians who went West in the Spring have died.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter advising that Cattaraugus Seneca have refused to sign a petition drafted by Tonawanda Senecas and enclosing statement of losses in money and goods for Ely's corrections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Decision has been reached in Council to send Chiefs Blacksmith and Shanks to be with Ely in Washington, so that "the blame might not rest upon him so strongly if we should happen to loose our lands." The full authority vested earlier in Ely is not to be affected by this decision.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brief letter advising brother not to include languages in his studies at Alexander.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter reporting briefly on the progress of the Tonawanda case before Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Committee on Indian Affairs has refused to exempt the Tonawanda Band from the provisions of the Treaty, on the grounds that it was ratified May 20, 1842 by the Senate, in spite of the same evidence of fraud, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Spencer has returned home and he and other members of the family are not well. Caroline has had another letter from L.H. Morgan and fears he is disappointed in her knowledge of Indian grammar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from Enterprise, Mo., stating that Isaac Love, who has been substituting as miller for Cone during the latter's absence, is to be superseded in April by a Mr. Britten who has apparently bribed the Chiefs to consent to his appointment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges letter from Ely, stating he and Goodwin have no money to send him. Suggests that Ely call on Mr. Yates and A.B. Street in Albany, who "are well off." Street is writing a poem on the Iroquois and Porter a history of the Ogden matter, and both authors will need Ely's help.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter to his parents requesting that they send him $20.00 at once as a loan. Ely has stopped for a few days in Albany to see the new Governor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clipping mentioning Indian lobby with names of delegates, the adoption by the Seneca of Lewis Henry Morgan, C. T. Porter and Thomas Darling, and other news items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two clippings dealing with Bills introduced before the State Legislature, one appropriating $2,000 to provide for the return East of the surviving emigrants, and another allowing $300 for school purposes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Abstract by Ely S. Parker of an address by an educated Indian delivered before the New York Historical Society, which contrasts the part played by the Iroquois in the development and history of the Empire State with their present unhappy position.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter enclosing a petition to the Secretary of War, signed by 25 customers of the mill, setting forth Cone's "claims as Seneca miller." Letter states the present incumbent, John Britton, is incompetent.

did.unittitle: ALS to William L. Marcy, Secretary of War

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Document with 2-1/2 pages of signatures in double columns, denying the existence of an "emigrationist party" and stating the Band is unanimous in preferring their lands to the Ogden Land Co.'s money for improvements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter requesting Ely to submit promptly Indian names, etc. for the 4 degrees of the "Hodenosonnee" secret society so that plans can be completed for an organization meeting in August.

did.unittitle: AMs, "New Initiation of the Wolf Tribe of the Cayuga Nation..."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "...one of the Confederate Nations of the Grand Confederacy of Iroquois." [i.e. Morgan's secret society.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: First page only of a letter written from Pembroke, N.Y., contesting his replacement as Miller within the Nosho sub-agency, by John Britton, a white man, and explaining that his absence since December was due to the appointment of himself and George Jemison as delegates to plead the cause in Washington of the emigrants and that their traveling funds gave out when they reached Buffalo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brief statement, signed by 15 chiefs, of expenditures totaling $5,079.31, spent in defense of national rights from 1838 to 1847.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter written from Buffalo, advising he can exert no further influence with regard to Ely's application for admission to Harvard University, and suggesting that he approach some Quaker friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A pious letter on the joy of living close to God, with a few brief references to mutual friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter asking advice on the use of Indian words in a poem he is writing, and promising that he and Mr. Yates will do their best to find a position in Albany for Ely.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from the Indian agent concerning arrangements for the payment of $400 to the Tonawanda chiefs and requesting a statement signed by them concerning "their wishes and determination in regard to the census."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A poem about faithful friends, inscribed at Tonawanda Mission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Original and typed copy of Power-of-Attorney, authorizing Ely S. Parker and Isaac Shanks to act on behalf of the Band. Document bears names and marks of 2 witnesses, 9 warriors and 16 chiefs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An 8 page diary entitled "Notes on the Road," covering incidents and personalities encountered in New York, Philadelphia and Washington.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Shanks, Isaac and Parker, Ely S.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The delegates report they gave $50 to Brown in Philadelphia as instructed, and that they have learned the Tonawandas' case died with the unfinished business of the last Congress. Shanks is ill.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Parker, Ely S. and Shanks, Isaac

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A summary statement by the delegates to the Commissioner of Indian Affairs of the difficulties between the Tonawanda Senecas and the Ogden Land Co. They will not accept any part of the payment for the improvements on their land, nor permit an appraisement of these improvements, as they were dissenting parties to the treaties which so provided.

did.unittitle: ALS to the Treasurer of the State of North Carolina

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request for information about funds held in trust, resulting from the sale of land formerly owned by the Tuscarora Indians.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A reply from the Treasurer of North Carolina, stating that the sale of Tuscarora lands yielded $3,220.71, which amount was paid to their agent in 1832.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Indian agent advises he believes the district attorney, under the Statute of 1813, can compel the county judge to issue warrants for removal of White intruders. Angel offers to pay Ely's board in exchange for services in Ellicottville. Would like to have Tonawanda census as soon as "your brother... gets it completed."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An invitation to visit a friend, with expenses paid, so that they can practice "a dialogue" for an "exhibition" in Newfane in March.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Instructions to Parker in Ellicottville to be at Cattaraugus April 5 to witness the signatures of Tonawanda chiefs on annuity receipts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newspaper clipping, entitled "Indians on Religion," signed Seneca.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Eight lines written in Seneca, in pencil, on a scrap of paper, without English translation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An unfinished reply to a request for a "succint account of the Tonawandas," and "the expulsion of the Eries."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notes on the following topics: History of the Iroquois Confederacy or Six Nations; International Rank and Relations; Geography; Astronomy; and Medicine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from Batavia, informing his brother that the Courts fined Ichabod Waldren $15.00, that other complaints have been made against the intruders, and that Blacksmith has received a letter from Brown concerning losses of money by Striker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Statement that William Parker, as part owner of the saw mill, is entitled "to $47.90 of the $100.00 payment."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from Ellicottville stating Ely will need money by September to attend the State fair in Buffalo, and that Mr. Angel has been replaced by Robert H. Shankland as Indian agent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from a friend, with comments on politics and news of family and friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Morgan cannot attend council on September 30 and requests Ely to send him a full report, including speeches of the orators, description of the ceremony of raising up sachems, the white dog sacrifice, etc., to be used in connection with a book Morgan plans to publish on the League of the Iroquois.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The new Indian Agent reports that the annuity money has been received and will be paid Oct. 18 to the heads of families, in accordance with a new method.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A notebook containing a report of speeches, etc., in pencil. Also typescript of same, with photostat of first and last pages of original.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mutilated manuscript describing "a Grand Council of the Six Nations of New York, held at Tonawanda for the purpose of hearing again their religious code, from Jimmy Johnson, the Grand High Priest of the Iroquois Confederacy."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter with news of the early victims of what may be a small pox epidemic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed "Speech of Wa-o-wa-wa-na-onk [Peter Wilson], addressed to the Committee of Baltimore Yearly Meeting of Friends on Indian Concerns, 10 mo. 29, 1848."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter requesting Seneca names for items in Morgan's Indian collection which, according to a plan of the Regents of the University, is to form a department of the State Geological Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Spencer advises his brother that the Supreme Court has decided a case in the Indians' favor. A council is to be held to decide on the manner in which annuities are to be paid. Smallpox is confined to Poodry's family and is not spreading.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A collection of essays with the following titles: The Young Twig; On Mohammed; The Wreath of Love; Time (dated Nov. 30, 1848); An Amateur President; Troubles of Life; Alphabetical Allitteration; Stray Thoughts; etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The father discusses Ely's letter of Nov. 20 "the contents of which is at so much variance to yours of the 20th ult." Contrary to Ely's later advice some of the Tonawandas are opposed to accepting the new method of annuity payments and are inclined to link it with the Ogden Co.'s efforts to appraise improvements. Wm. Parker accuses Dr. Wilson at Cattaraugus of being "the main and prime mover of our present difficulties."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from a friend, extolling the pleasures and amusements available in Bellevue, Ohio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter advising Parker of the disappointing results of calls on newspaper editors, which Morgan has made as requested in an attempt to secure work for Ely as a correspondent should he decide to go West. As an inducement to "abandon his Western notions," Morgan tells Ely of contacts he has made to secure employment for him with the State's Genessee Valley Canal project. Asks him again for a description by Johnson of the white dog sacrifice and for a few more Indian words.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter advising there will be no vacancy for Parker until the Spring.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter enclosing Pomeroy's reply of Dec. 23.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Warren, who has been recently married, reports that "Wadsworth, surveyors and appraisers" have been driven off by the Indians and that Sheriff Sprague and the Secretary of War refused to aid the efforts of these Ogden agents to appraise the Tonawandas' improvements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter commenting on Parker's new position and giving news of friends. Warren also reports that "Wadsworth and Co." are attempting to appraise improvements through information obtained from White informers. He encloses an article from the Democrat, to which he urges Parker to reply giving the Indians' side of the Ogden matter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An acknowledgement of Parker's letter of Feb. 16. Warren is glad to know Ely likes his new work. He states "California is all the rage here." The number of Sons of Temperance is compared to the larger membership among the Odd Fellows and Masons in Bellevue.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brief note advising Parker he has written Mr. Brown, informing him that Wadsworth is in Washington, urging the appointment of a new appraiser to replace Mr. Love, who is expected to resign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Incomplete letter to the Secretary of War, objecting to the application of the Ogden Co. for a new appraiser to replace Thomas C. Love.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typed copy of power-of-attorney, signed by 18 chiefs, authorizing Nicholson H. Parker to "speak, act and decide," on their behalf in dealing with officers of the state and federal governments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A report of the arbitrators in the Ogden matter, describing the circumstances and data on which their appraisal of the Tonawanda improvements is based, together with a letter from the Department of the Interior, stating the document was accepted for the record only and is without an "official character."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An acknowledgment of Ely's letter and its $10 enclosure.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter stating he is no longer interested in becoming Indian Agent at Ellicottville. Rice believes Osborn will be appointed to the post and that Shankland's hopes of being retained "will prove fallacious."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nic has received a letter from W. P. Angel, advising him to go to Lee and Co.'s bank in Buffalo to get money to bring the surviving Indians back from the West. He hesitates going without proof that the commission has been assigned to him officially.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nic acknowledges Angel's letter of May 12, advising him that money is on hand for his trip to the West to bring back surviving Cayugas. Nic requests instructions of an official character for identification purposes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Policy covering five years fire insurance (1849-54), in the amount of $1,000, on house, farm buildings, personal effects, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter offering to secure work for his brother at $1.25 a day on the canal between Canadea and Olean.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter enclosing money in part payment of articles the Parker family are making and collecting for him. Morgan expects to visit Tonawanda at the end of the month.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter to Newton who has decided to return to school, encouraging and advising him in the matter of his studies. Morgan plans to send $2 each to Caroline and Nick in January in payment for moccasins and silverware, etc. He asks for Indian equivalents for a brief list of words.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed specification for excavations, locks, bridges, culverts, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter signed `your brother Charles' acknowledging gifts of Indian bead and basket work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter telling Ely about a vacancy with the Engineer Corps at Lockport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Document, signed by 11 chiefs and 6 warriors, nullifying the sale of Lucy Parker's land by Lewis Poodry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter offering Ely a position as rodman on the Allegany River, under D.F. DeWitt at Little Valley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note stating that at the time of the surrender of its charter in 1848, Ely S. Parker was a member in good standing of Batavia Lodge No. 88.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A descriptive letter about her studies, teachers and classmates at the Albany State Normal School, which Caroline is attending with her brothers Newton and Nicholas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter of parental advice to be a good boy and improve his mind.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An incoherent letter, written to a sister apparently, concerning $20 which the writer wishes to borrow until he receives his salary as a teacher in the employ of Howard Nott in Union.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter to his sister at School, telling her to work hard and keep an eye on Newton. Ely has had favorable reports of her progress from Christopher Morgan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from a boy friend in Pavilion Centre, which refers to their mutual friend Nett and a Ruth M. Bradly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter thanking Ely for reporting the speeches "in such fine language," and requesting information on the relationship between Cornplanter and Handsome Lake.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter stating he will send brooches and rattlesnakes as soon as possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter advising it seems a little too late to catch the rattlesnakes Nicholson has requested, and that the annual council will take place at Tonawanda on the 17th. This letter is signed `Gau-nos-qua.'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Seneca text, without English, beginning "gan Dih ok nah 26 1850. Goh Da gas ga oh gr nok Dr yeh." 1-1/2 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from a former school mate with news of mutual friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Book of roots, or of words supposed to be roots... in the Seneca language." 4 pages in a small notebook inscribed at Allegany Mission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A reply, addressed to Pembroke, acknowledging Newton's letter of October, and advising him that "his note to Miss Elizabeth" had been forwarded to New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newton would like to receive more mail from the family. Nick and he have lost their pocketbooks and some suspicion attaches to a student from Cattaraugus. Wishes to be addressed as Newton I. Parker, the I to stand for Isaac.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "The Indian Prophet," a corrected essay on Handsome Lake.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Incomplete draft of a letter to postpone a petition to the Legislature to appoint an attorney for the Tonawanda Indians.

did.unittitle: ALS to Editor of the Albany Atlas

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a plan for the speedy enlargement of the Erie Canal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reported by Mr. Varnum, in relation to measures for testing the title of land on the Tonawanda Indian Reservation. Two printed copies and original manuscript.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ely thanks his brother for buying the shirts he ordered and sends him money, although he is as `poor as a church mouse' himself. He advises Nic to remain at school so as 'to get as good an education as it is possible for you to get.'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reported by Mr. Burroughs, to authorize the laying out of a public highway on the bank of the Tonawanda and Oak Orchard canal feeder, with an amendment in manuscript to the effect that only Indians can settle on the said feeder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Memorandum concerning money borrowed, to the amount of $433.25, for the purpose of sending a delegation to Albany.

did.unittitle: ALS to A. H. H. Stuart

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter to the Secretary of the Interior, protesting the removal of Dr. Peter Wilson as interpreter for the New York Agency.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter discussing copies of canal estimates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from the newly appointed Indian Agent stating he does `not feel free to interfere with what I believe to be the preference at Washington' to retain Dr. Peter Wilson as his interpreter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brief letter advising that Jesse Tiffany and Ya-de-sose died Apr. 18 and Joh-doh on May 4. Charles Doctor and Eli Johnson are at school in Aurora. The letter is signed Gau-nos-qua.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter of encouragement, expressing pleasure at his progress in school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from Washington, thanking Ely for a gift copy of Morgan's "League of the Iroquois."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nick asks his brother for help in finding work during the summer vacation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ely advises his brother that if the Bill for speedy enlargement of the Canal passes, he may be able to get him a job with the Engineers Dept.

did.unittitle: "Wild roved an Indian girl, bright Alfarata"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rough copy of what appears to be the words of a song. Verso of paper has notations concerning an increase in weight from Mar. to June 1851.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A confidential letter informing Ely of a meeting with Mr. Fellows in Albany and of the latter's plan to "attempt to pay improvement money to the Tonawandas."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter advising that Nic's services as interpreter are needed at a trial in Batavia, and that in spite of some opposition on the part of Isaac Shanks and Jimmy Johnson that Parker will probably be made sachem. Letter signed Gaunosqua.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of a Council held for the purpose of celebrating the funeral rites of John Blacksmith, at which Ely S. Parker was proclaimed his successor as Grand Sachem of the Six Nations, and Spencer C. Parker and 8 others were installed as war chiefs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A circular prepared by the Superintendent of Common Schools containing information to guide Town Superintendents in filling student vacancies at the State Normal School.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Second page only of a letter suggesting that Ely see Mr. Wadsworth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter advising that the four shirts ordered have been sent by express to Rochester.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A vague letter to the effect the writer is willing to use his influence to bring about an arrangement to the advantage of the Indians, the Ogden Co. and the neighboring communities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A confidential letter asking Spencer to use his influence on the writer's behalf in connection with the forthcoming state elections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter requesting Ely to reserve a room at a reputable hotel for the use of the writer's brothers during the fair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brief letter concerning arrangements for forwarding Nic's luggage, share of annuities, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from a correspondent, now teaching school in Cynthiana, Ky., dealing with the marvels of modern travel, Cuban politics, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter, in which reference is made to Ely's having been elected Sachem, asking him to have some baggage forwarded from Rochester to Buffalo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from a friend attending school in Albany, describing vacation activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter expressing hope that Nic will soon be well enough to return to school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from the Secretary of War, complying with a request to furnish a copy of President Fillmore's instructions to Benjamin Pringle, the agent appointed to disburse improvement monies to the Tonawandas. The copy of the instructions, enclosed with the Secretary's letter, is dated June 26, 1851.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certified extract from the Minutes of the Board, signed by F.H. Ruggles, relative to Ely's appointment as First Assistant Engineer on the Canals of the State.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter of encouragement and advice about school work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brief letter from Engineer's Office at Lyons about payments to Nic in Oct. and Nov.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Torn page of a diary begun at the "house of W. W. Moore, corner of Spring and Hawk No. 37 in the city of Albany..."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A confidential letter concerning purchasing a half interest in a Lock project with an Albert Hall.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Instructions to a Division Engineer to furnish Mr. Conger, a member of the Senate Investigating Committee with copies of contracts and other information required by the Committee.

did.unittitle: ALS to James White and John Burns

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of lease to April 1854 of about 150 acres of land with house and barn on the Tonawanda Reservation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter enclosing lease with White and Burns, asking his father to see that it is signed by them and its faithful performance guaranteed by a responsible party.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter to his father quoting an extract from the laws of 1841 (!) by which "it is proposed to commence the action against the settlers and other Whites upon the Tonawanda Reservation."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of a petition to invoke the Act of March 31, 1821 for removing White settlers on Indian lands by Aug. 20.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter advising that Ely and Martindale concur it would be unwise to start any more suits until the Blacksmith case and the case of removing settlers under the law of 1821 are settled.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A plea against the removal of Red Jacket's remains to Forest Lawn Cemetery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from a friend in the Treasury Dept., Washington, advising he will be glad to cooperate by sending Public Documents to Ely and Richard V. when requested to do so.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter stating he hopes to graduate next term and advising "we have been moving to 15 Lancaster," which prevented Nic's writing sooner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter expressing views on the leasing of water power, quarries, etc. to parties other than Indians.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter referring to Ely's unsettled employment, plans for the summer, business interests at Tonawanda, and eagerness to learn the decision of the Court of Appeals. The letter is addressed to "Sir Isaac Newton Parker."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from an uncle asking for instructions on the duties of his office as sub-sachem.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from a friend, suggesting he attend a meeting at which Gov. Kossuth will speak and asking for an advance of $50.00.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter advising that two of the three volumes requested have been sent by express and that the third volume will not be out until the next Congress. The books were apparently secured through the cooperation of [Daniel] Webster.

did.unittitle: ALS to Ely Parker and J. H. Martindale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter suggesting that a delegation be sent to Washington to protest against the re-appointment of Benjamin Pringle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter replying that Ely `cannot dictate to George Cooper what he shall say or do in councils' and that he and Mr. Martindale concur that it would be `impolitic' to do anything about Pringle's agency before the Court of Appeals renders a decision. This letter also is addressed to "Sir Isaac Newton Parker."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A reply to Ely's letter of June 21, acknowledging receipt of the books, and concluding with a discussion of national politics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request that Nic call on Mr. Scoville of W.C. Little and Co.'s book store to make certain adjustments on a subscription to Merry's Museum and Parley Magazine ordered sent to his son, Rush Spencer Wilson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ely will try to be at Batavia to enter protest at land sale and does not believe that the sale should cause worry on his father's part.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A school friend reports from South Valley that he called on Robert [?] Watt as requested and was told that an annuity payment of $4.75 has been "left in the care of Peter Crouse, who lives in Coldspring," but that the payment six years in arrears is not ready.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ely writes at the request of the widow Blacksmith to explain and apologize for being dilatory in acknowledging a letter of condolence written by Brown sometime last summer. Brown's letter was taken from the Post Office by J.A. Sanford and not delivered because of Sanford's death. Ely's letter is signed as "Chief and Successor to Blacksmith."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter enclosing estimates of engineering expenses and reporting that cholera deaths are declining in Rochester.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A superintendent of the Thomas Indian School writes at the suggestion of a Mr. Thompson for confirmation of an Iroquois tradition concerning Logan, a Cayuga chief, to whose memory it is proposed to erect a monument near his birthplace. Brantz Mayer, President of the Maryland Historical Society, `in an effort to redeem the character of the Cresap family with which he has connections, has contradicted facts of Logan's life long held by early settlers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A newsy letter from home reporting that Caroline has postponed until Spring her plan to earn needed money teaching, because she has not been well and is kept very busy with household chores. Mary Jemison died July 18. Nic and Dr. Wilson have been home on a visit. She discusses the tenants' farm crops and Levi Parker's drinking and love affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter giving measurements and diagrams of farm land leased to White and Burns. Mutilated - part of second page missing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Comment on an attached newspaper clipping from the Rochester Advertiser, in which Ely claims his statement as to how he would vote, if he possessed the franchise, has been misrepresented. The clipping refers to his speech at a rally for the democratic nominees in the national elections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typewritten copy of a published reply to Hall's inquiry of Aug. 12, in which Ely outlines the Iroquois `traditional history' concerning Chief Logan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter of brotherly advice concerning Newton's health, school work and clothing. Ely expects to be at Cattaraugus when the annuities are paid and "to make some fuss among the Indians" in connection with the Stryker money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter of thanks for some clothes which `suit well all over and all around.' Nic and Lucia Green are back at school and there are 12 Iroquois students, two more than the number limited by law. Newton's neck is getting better.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter of appreciation prompted by the favorable results of suits in the Court of Appeals. Timber is being taken by settlers and they would like Martindale to devise a means by which the Indians may receive compensation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fragment of mutilated letter, commenting on social and educational opportunities available in Albany, the successful outcome of the Tonawanda suits in the Court of Appeals, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter to the Commissioner of Indian Affairs about the non-payment by the Indian Agent of the "Stryker defalcation" and other annuities, stressing the Tonawandas' need of the money and their autonomy within the Seneca tribe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An editorial discussing an accompanying financial report of Nov. 11 by the Auditor of the Canal Fund to the Commissioners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter stating that according to inquiries Dr. Fleming is "a gentleman of integrity and pecuniary responsibility."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from an applicant for the office of Indian Agent for New York State, soliciting Ely's influence on his behalf and mentioning as references Hon. R.C. Fenton and former Indian agents Washburn and Angel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A recommendation of J. D. Wheat for the New York Indian sub-agency. A rough draft, signed as Grand Sachem of the Six Nations of Indians in New York and Canada.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from an old friend, discussing current national politics, which may result in Warren, a Whig, losing his office as postmaster at Alabama, in favor of Mr. Johnson, a Democrat.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter giving information concerning title to land on the Oil Spring Reservation, purchased by the Holland Land Co. and currently claimed by Governor Seymour and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of a statement by the Secretary of War that the filing of the "document purporting to be the Award or Report of Horace Gay and Ira Cook" is a formality that does not determine the legality or validity of the document.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter of instructions concerning the methods the Indians should pursue, should the Sheriff receive warrants to eject White settlers, and advising that the improvement money in Pringle's hands need cause no fear, because according to the decision of the Court of Appeals, no appraisal of improvements has yet been made and without it the Ogden Co. cannot claim title to the land.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter advising that Asa Cutler and two others have been notified by the Sheriff to remove from their residences and stating that William Parker would like the Sachem's advice with regard to calling on the Cattaraugus Indians as witnesses, should the evicted settlers contest their rights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed announcement of "Indian Historical Lectures, by Ga-i-wah-go-wa" [N. H. Parker] in full Indian costume in Seminary Hall, Canandaigua.

did.unittitle: ALS to the President of the U.S.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request, signed as Grand Sachem of the Six Nations of Indians in New York and Canada, that Peter Wilson be continued as interpreter for the New York Indian agency.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter advising that J.D. Wheat has arrived in Albany, thereby missing Ely's letter of recommendation and requesting that another be sent to Wilson by return mail to enable Wilson "to proceed immediately to the South."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter calling Osburn's unfavorable report of the Tonawandas to Ely's notice. Schoolcraft presumes the new agent will be a "compromise Democrat."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An acknowledgment of Schoolcraft's letter, in which Ely refutes Osborn's assertion the Tonawandas are "surely but slowly retrograding," but agreeing with him that the old form of government should be restored at Cattaraugus and Allegany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of a letter of thanks to a New York senator "for the promptness with which the Assembly Bill for the survey of the Onondagas' Indian lands was repudiated." The survey was to be made for the purpose of apportioning the land to individual Indians, "thereby destroying that bond of common interest which unites and holds Indian communities together."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request for advice in settling a dispute about the proportionate division of farm land at Tonawanda between the lessees, Burns and White.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Social note apologizing for not bidding him and Sophy goodbye before they left Binghamton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A brief acknowledgment of a gift sent by Newton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from the Commissioner of Indian Affairs advising that Marcus H. Johnson will succeed S. Osborne as sub-agent for the New York Indians, and that settlement of the Stryker defalcation fund has been delayed because of a claim set up by the Buffalo band of Senecas, the validity of which will be decided upon shortly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter advising that $400 has been collected for Ely's trip to Washington and that the new agent, Marcus Johnson, has written a letter stating the Stryker money will be paid as soon as he has been informed by the Indians of the results of their census.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of a letter dealing with the following matters: 1) Recall of Benjamin Pringle; 2) Payment of annuities directly to the Tonawandas and their recognition as a separate band; 3) Cognizance of the fact that Phillip E. Thomas was appointed representative in Washington of the Cattaraugus and Allegheny Senecas only - that he does not represent the views or sentiments of the Tonawandas who were not included in the Act of incorporation; 4) Protest against the unfavorable report of Agent Osborn dated Sept. 30, 1852.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter telling of disputes with the Cattaraugus band over the Tonawandas' share of the Stryker fund and other monies. The Tonawandas are opposed to the Cattaraugus plan to appropriate the money for the erection and maintenance of an Indian school. Newton has written that he likes Indiana.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from Girard, Pa. stating he is happy and "getting better all the while since I began to have a little exercise." Newton and Henry hope to be able to send money home in about two weeks. Asks that mail be sent to Pittsburgh, Pa., addressed to him as "Okatawaule (Indian Chief)" a name bestowed on him by Washburn whom he has met in his travels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ely has received a complaint through William Jimeson that Nic has withheld money due to Harriette. Nic writes his brother to explain that he withheld the money temporarily until Harriette would consent to deducting money she owes William Parker from the amount given to Nic for her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request that Ely find time to see Mr. Henry Ely of Rochester who wants to talk to him about a building to be erected by Star and Childs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Handwritten copy of a letter to the Secretary of State [!], the original of which is in the New York Public Library, concerning Ely's misinterpretation of the provisions of an Act limiting the number of Indian pupils, which had led to their selection on the basis of reservations instead of on population.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An account of expenditures for "the education of Indian youths at Tonawanda," from the Trustee to the Superintendent of Common Schools, covering the period June 22 to Aug. 29.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from the Deputy Superintendent of Common Schools, returning Parker's statement and pointing out that receipts as well as expenditures are required by Chapter 351 of the Law of 1851.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from a friend now working as Foreign Money Teller for the American Express Bank, inquiring about former canal associates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The writer suggests an exchange of letters `for our own amusement and instruction' dealing with Indian history and ethnology.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from a friend spending the winter in Iowa City "in the honorable employment of lobbying," containing comments on politics and social life in Iowa and references to mutual friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note addressed to "Sir Knight Parker" requesting remittance in the amount of $8.00 for embroidered gauntlets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ely's advice is needed about renting a house which some prospective tenants wish to convert into a grist mill at a cost of about $20,000.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note advising that someone should pick up tickets for return fares from Buffalo to Syracuse, which have been secured at half price through Mr. Stockton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request for information concerning ownership of the Oil Spring Reservation, title to which is claimed by Jake Shongo, Ben Chamberlain and lawyer Hammon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A suggestion that the Iroquois Indians still own the Thousand Islands on the Canadian side of the border, which according to rumor are not claimed by the government.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The State has appropriated $40,000 to the Oneidas for land sold by them or their forefathers. Descendants of this tribe, settled at Onondaga and Allegany, wish to employ Ely and Nic to claim their share of the money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Colonel acknowledges Ely's apology, refuses his resignation from the regiment, and promises that when he retires "no one will do more to have you promoted than I."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An announcement, printed in Seneca and English, of a Council to be held at Cattaraugus Reservation to decide upon an amendment to the Constitution of the Seneca Nation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Describes his trip from Rochester to Cedar Falls, Iowa, in the company of Hank Packard and his family, with references to mutual friends encountered en route.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter requesting "a little counsel and assistance" for her forthcoming book which will "tell the bright side of the story concerning Indian life and character." Her book on "The Iroquois..." was published 1855 under the pseudonym Minnie Myrtle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from a correspondent attending school in Albany, inquiring about Newton's whereabouts and wishing him success with his `managery.' Suggests she write to P.H. Jimerson, `a nice young man' at Jonesville.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter of introduction for Theron Seymour of Oswego.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Commissioner calls attention to the Act of June 27, 1846 whereby the funds held in trust for the Senecas by the Bank cannot be transferred to the custody of the U.S. without the consent of the Indians.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advises the deep snow prevented his reaching Tonawanda. Would appreciate Ely's securing for him the services of some of Washburn's men `when they come home' and of his brother [Newton] who is in the South.

did.unittitle: Military Association of the State of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Circular, addressed to Ely S. Parker, announcing the third annual convention of the Association in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A resolution, signed by Henry Two Guns, as President, and Maris B. Pierce, as Clerk, that the Tonawanda Band receive their per capita share of the Greig and Gibson fund.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A chatty letter describing Albany's celebration of the Whig victory. Wright advises confidentially that if and when Peter Wilson is displaced as interpreter, Nic should "take steps to fill the vacancy." The American Bible Society has promised aid and Wright hopes Nick will soon finish translating John. There are brief references to Minnie [Myrtle], Newton, John Hudson and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A discussion of the transfer of the Greig and Gibson fund.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request for information concerning the measures decided upon by the Department of Indian Affairs "respecting the anticipated payment...of the Greig and Gibson annuity."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Bank will transfer the trust fund to the President of the United States on June 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cousin William Moses would like Ely to secure a job on a farm for his 14 year old son. Newton is in Hartford, Conn. The family want Ely to use his influence in persuading Newton to return home, away from the influence of Jesse Jemison, a married woman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request for the Division Engineer's advice on how to handle a difficult situation. Mr. Britton refuses to "quit work" unless served with a written notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A recommendation of a man named Hine for a position as rodman or leveler.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cost data on locks nos. 65 and 66, assigned to Jesse Peterson and Charles H. Britton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter stating the writer is glad to be away from Cattaraugus, "a miserable place," and advising of a change of address to 184 Lancaster Street, Albany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note advising that a communication from the chiefs should be published "as is" without revision.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A brief letter addressed to Dr. Parker, stating she is glad he is studying medicine, and advising she is thinking of going to school this winter, requesting that he make an application to the Superintendent at Albany for her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Caroline writes that she is "teaching now and board myself." Father won't know until April when the trial comes up whether Nic will be needed in Albany. There are "all sorts of flying stories" in Tonawanda because C[hauncy] C. Jemison has called on Caroline.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Minutes of "Old Party Caucus" with names of officers nominated.

did.unittitle: Commercial Bank of N.J., Perth Amboy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A one dollar bill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An invitation to visit the writer in Indianapolis with offer of a pass on the Bellefontaine Line.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter enclosing pension voucher for Sept. 4 and advising there is little hope for Parker's petition to have his pension increased.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of a letter advising the Commissioner that the Tonawandas are about to send a delegation to Washington to protest the appointment of another agent to disburse the Ogden improvement money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An acknowledgment of Ely's letter of Sept. 25 stating that he sees no necessity for sending a delegation to Washington, as the Office of Indian Affairs does not contemplate appointing an agent to pay the improvement fund.

did.unittitle: Letters of Marcus H. Johnson, Frederick Follett, N.E. Paine, and I.A. Verplank, to Franklin Pierce, William L. Marcy and R. McClelland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copies of letters protesting the appointment of an agent to disburse the Ogden improvement fund.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Parker, Ely S. and Parker, Nicholson H.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of a petition to the President summarizing the Ogden Co.'s efforts to appraise improvements at Tonawanda and the Indians' refusal to accept any part of the Company's "award" for same.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Memorandum concerning the Tonawanda delegation's conference with the President, F. Pierce, to present the Indians' protest against the appointment of a new agent to pay the Ogden Co.'s improvement fund.

did.unittitle: Membership certificate in Historical Society of Pennsylvania

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Signed by Horatio Gates Jones, Secretary.

did.unittitle: Abstract of Fellows v. Blacksmith and Parker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed abstract of case of Joseph Fellows, plaintiff, vs. Blacksmith and Parker, defendants. Joshua L. Brown, counsel for plaintiff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List of "Goods for 1856" consisting of blankets, calico, etc., valued at $611.49.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter, addressed to Ely as Superintendent of the U.S. Marine Hospital, Galena, Ill., concerning the Company's willingness to adjust their error in weighing girders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Company wants to know if Newton and his troupe can be depended on to join their show next summer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy in E.S. Parker's hand of an amendment to a proposal to sell to the U.S. a site for the new Marine Hospital, Galena. The amendment concerns the location of the section to be retained for McCarty's own use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Memorandum of the points made by R.H. Gillett in the Argument before the U.S. Supreme Court in the Tonawanda case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Record of 54 vaccinations at Tonawanda giving age of each Indian. Names are grouped by families.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note stating he is pleased to have secured Ely's services for the government and will see him in Detroit March 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deed covering sale of land for the new Marine Hospital, Galena, for the sum of $5,052.00.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ely requests his father to give notice to the Tonawanda Band of a general council, which he will attend with Martindale to report on their success in Washington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of a letter to the Secretary of the Treasury, Washington, concerning the new Marine Hospital in Galena, covering deed for its site, progress in construction, material to be used, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Part of a draft of a letter concerning stone for the Custom House in Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter acknowledging communications from the Secretary of the Treasury, Washington, concerning the construction of public buildings in Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgment of the Secretary of the Treasurer's reply to Ely's letter of April 29 [q.v.].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgments of the Secretary of the Treasurer's letters of May 5th and 6th concerning Custom House lot and estimates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A chatty letter, with references to mutual friends in Detroit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A reply to Blair's letter, containing an unflattering description of Westerners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Power of attorney for John H. Martindale, Isaac Verplank, and Ely S. Parker, to transact business with officials of the U.S. Government in Washington. Signed by 23 chiefs, warriors, etc.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Parker, Ely S.; Martindale, John H.; Bryan, William G.; and Follett, Frederick

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An outline of the measures suggested by the Tonawanda delegation as a means of settling the Indians' dispute with the Ogden Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newspaper clipping concerning the object of the Tonawanda delegation in Washington, which includes Ely S. Parker, F. Follett, W.C. Bryan and J.H. Martindale.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of a letter listing enclosed drawings for Customs House and Marine Hospital.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report of operations for May and June on the new Customs House, Galena, Ill., to the Secretary of the Treasury, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Construction report for April, May and June, on the new Marine Hospital, Galena, Ill., to the Secretary of the Treasury, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of a letter to the Secretary of the Treasury, concerning estimated cost of constructing the foundation for the new Customs House.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newspaper clipping of a report to the Chairman of the Committee on Lock and Dam, concerning the quantity of water available for, and the estimated cost of constructing a lock on the Galena River, together with brief editorial comment on same.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Form letter concerning material ordered from Cooper, Hewitt and Co. of New York for the Galena Custom House.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from a friend in Leavenworth, Kansas, discussing the slavery issue, corrupt politics, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bill for labor and materials in excavating cisterns in Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Part of an agreement between the city of Galena, Ill., and the U.S.A. for a plot of ground fronting on Green, Water and Commerce Streets, in Galena.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Parker, Ely S.; Parker, Nicholson H.; Martindale, J.H.; Bryan, William G.; and Follett, Frederick

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of an agreement between the Tonawanda delegation and the Commissioner of Indian Affairs, providing for purchase of the Indians' lands from the Ogden Co. out of funds put aside by the U.S. Government for the Indians' removal and support West of the Missouri.

did.unittitle: Politics and its corruptions in northwestern Illinois

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed copy of an address, on pp. 7-8 of which are the speaker's remarks in defense of Ely S. Parker as Superintendent of Public Works in Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typewritten copy of a newspaper clipping from the issue of January 9, 1858, concerning the Treaty of Nov. 5, 1857, between the Tonawandas and the U.S. Government, in settlement of the Ogden land dispute.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Census of the Tonawanda Band by heads of families.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter concerning details of an annuity payment at Tonawanda. B.H. Colgrove has been appointed agent for the New York Indians.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Agreement covering transfer of contract dated Mar. 25, 1857, for the construction of Custom House, Post Office and Marine Hospital at Galena, Ill.

did.unittitle: Specifications for building the Custom-House and Post Office, at Galena, Ill.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: U.S. Treasury Department. Office of the Construction of Buildings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed item.

did.unittitle: Specifications for building the Marine Hospital at Galena, Illinois

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: U.S. Treasury Department. Office of the Construction of Buildings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed item.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous memoranda concerning plans, work, and expenditures on public buildings in Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note from the Pension Office re. the issuance of a new pension certificate for William Parker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invalid Pension Certificate authorizing payments of $8.00 a month to William Parker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Quarterly return of materials, machinery, etc. for the Custom House and Marine Hospital, Galena, Ill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Receipt for $24.75 covering cost of publication in Albany Journal of notice that sealed proposals for work on the Erie Canal must be received at the Commissioner's office by Apr. 5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from a friend in Philadelphia advising that he has obtained a facsimile of the Penn Wampum Belt, which he would like to deliver to Ely in person, and asking where he can obtain a copy of the poem "Yonondio" by W.H.C. Hosmer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Census, by head of family, giving number of men, women, children, deaths, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Memoranda as to money expended by Frederick E. Geiger in the construction of the Custom House and Marine Hospital, Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bill for $65.00 for labor on Custom House, Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Because of prejudice against their `system' there will be no students from Cattaraugus for the `Catholic college,' but Father Doran has visited Tonawanda to interview prospective students from there. At a council held at Cattaraugus to discuss the Kansas land claims of New York Indians, it was decided to send 2 delegates from each tribe to Washington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of a letter from the Superintendent of the new Custom House, at Nauvoo, Ill., to the foreman of Bostater and Fents, notifying him to suspend quarrying operations and to turn over lists in his possession concerning dimensions of required stone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notice of transfer and sale of goods in possession of John Lorrain, on behalf of F.E. Geiger, for use in the construction of Custom House and Marine Hospital, Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Memorandum concerning stone work completed by Bostater and Fents prior to receiving instructions to suspend operations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request that Lusk address a meeting of the Miner's Lodge, Galena, on January 7.

origination.label: creator

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notification that Gear has been elected an honorary member of Miner's Lodge.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note stating he has mailed a copy of Boudinot's "Star in the West" to Ely at Pembroke.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Martindale has not yet been to Tonawanda to help settle matters connected with the Indians' purchase of their land. Newton spent four weeks at Cattaraugus, but failed to come home `to see his boy' because the family have not written to him. Caroline has received another letter from Mr. Hurd.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter referring to a quarrel between the partners, Bostater and Fents, contractors for the Dubuque Custom House, and enclosing correspondence "unofficially forwarded" to keep the Superintendent advised.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Receipts for $100 and $75 for labor in fitting up Mitchell's Hall, Calena, as a Masonic lodge room.

scopecontent.p: Receipted bill for $4.00.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter to an old friend, explaining an unfilled promise to call on her [?] and Mr. and Mrs. Colman when he was in New York in August.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter inquiring when the final settlement will be made for work on the Custom House and Marine Hospital, Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Three mail wrappers addressed to Ely at Galena, Ill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reply stating he expects to render a final statement to Washington in a week or ten days and that he must first carry out instructions "to examine the accounts of the contractors" to determine the amount due Mr. Geiger for his share of the construction of the public buildings in Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Statement of quantities and specifications for grading and paving the Custom House grounds in Galena and for furnishing the building ready for occupancy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for approval of the appointment of William Davis as watchman at the Galena Marine Hospital.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A reply to Ely's inquiry, from the Secretary of the Illinois Stone Co., Chicago, enclosing a printed price list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter written on Illinois State Penitentiary stationery, advising that Messrs. Sawyer and Carey, the Superintendent and Warden, will write Ely "upon the subject of stone." Ely is invited to Joliet to dedicate a new Masonic Hall on Dec. 27.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter advising that Samuel B. Leaken of Galena has been authorized to act for the writer in collecting an amount due him from Mr. Geiger.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Martindale wants Ely to go to Albany with him to have legislation passed empowering Tonawanda chiefs to arrest, and fine or imprison, Indians who sell timber to Whites. There has been quarreling on the reservation over occupancy of houses vacated by the Whites. Levi has been quite sick.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgment of a remittance for $2 to cover subscription to "The Voice of Masonry..." to be sent to W.R. Rowley and J.B. Booth of Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mail wrapper addressed to Ely at Dubuque.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter returning Stewart's clain against F.E. Geiger, advising there is no balance due Geiger from his partner in connection with the construction of public buildings in Galena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of a reply from the Secretary of the Department of the Interior to the Commissioner of Indian Affairs, concerning the claims of New York Indians to land in Kansas Territory. The Secretary concurs that the provisions of the Treaty of 1838 should apply only to those Indians living in New York in 1838 and settled in Kansas on March 21, 1859. The claims of Indians not on "the census list submitted by Special Agent Stevens" need not be investigated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note requesting approval of sale of an unused furnace, stove, etc. at Galena Custom House.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note discussing Lodge accounts and other details.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certificate signed by the Secretary of the Chapter at Rochester that "Ely S. Parker is... a Royal Arch Mason in good and regular standing."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from a fellow Mason accepting Ely's offer to superintend carpentry work on Dubuque Custom House, with references to mutual friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter inquiring if Ely will attend a masonic meeting in Chicago on May 17.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter concerning the purchase of land at Tonawanda by the Parker family. Fifty acres have been added to Ely's farm, as compensation to the Grand Sachem for his services. Nick states it has always been his intention to return to Tonawanda some day and that he has made no permanent settlement at Cattaraugus.

origination.label: creator

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certificate, signed by the Grand Master and Grand Secretary of the Grand Lodge of Iowa, appointing Ely S. Parker a representative "to strengthen ties of brotherly affection" etc. between the Iowa and Illinois lodges.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter outlining the Grand Master B.B. French's directions for "forming around the triangle in military order."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notification from the Cashier of the Bank of Albany that William Parker's pension for $47.75 has been received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter asking for advice about renting to an individual who "wants to sow wheat on our old place..."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A draft list of accusations against W. Spalding, a member of the Lodge.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Receipt from Great Western Dispatch for freight charges on 69 boxes of glass.

scopecontent.p: List of items, broken or damaged, in shipment of glass for new Custom House, Dubuque.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request that Corwin support Bryant's recommendation of I.G. Palmer for Postmaster at Urbana.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Statement of mouldings required to complete work on the new Custom House, Dubuque.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Receipted bill for clothing bought between Sept. and Jan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Authorization to deliver to bearer materials for Dubuque Custom House.
