origination.persname: New York Indians in Kansas Territory

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notarized power-of-attorney in prosecuting claims under treaties of 1838 and 1842. Document bears names and marks of 12 chiefs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An invitation, written at the request of Brother Hunkins, to attend a meeting of the Miner's Lodge, Galena, on Mar. 15.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgment by the Secretary of the Treasury of Ely's report of operations for March at the Dubuque Custom House.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request for blank forms and instructions for filling in same for "Invalid Pensioners."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Power-of-attorney authorizing G.C. Clark to collect at Albany a pension payment for the period March 4 to September 4, 1861.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from the Acting Commissioner of Indian Affairs "enclosing an Act of the Legislature of the State of New York authorizing the Comptroller...to hold the Tonawanda Indian Reservation in trust...as contamplated by the treaty of March 31, 1859."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter concerning illness, death and funeral of Elizabeth Parker, "our dear and beloved mother."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from the Commissioner of Indian Affairs, replying to Ely's inquiry of the 5th, advising there is nothing to prevent the Indians from volunteering for war service, but that "there is nothing compulsory in the matter."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typewritten copy of a letter advising that the Mustering Officer at Buffalo has received belated instructions to enroll 300 Indian recruits, and that in this connection, Capt. Jemison will visit Tonawanda, probably accompanied by Cusick and the writer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of a bill for $35.40, rendered by the Sheriff of Genessee County, for serving eviction notices to 12 White settlers on the Tonawanda Reservation, at the request of District Attorney, James M. Willett.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter to the Secretary of State, Albany, asking to be kept informed about the proposed proceedings of the Seneca Nation at Cattaraugus and Allegany "to enjoin the Seneca state annuity."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Part of a petition or letter concerning the appropriation, by the Seneca Nation at Cattaraugus and Allegany, of the whole of the $500 state annuity provided by the Treaty of 1815, thus robbing the Tonawandas of their equitable share.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A brief note in which Ely states "your synopsis of Cusick's traditions...is admirably done," and apologises for the delay in replying to other questions returned with the letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An acknowledgment from the Acting Commissioner of Indian Affairs of the Memorial on behalf of the New York Indians in Kansas Territory which "will doubtless be submitted to Congress."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pencilled notes in leather bound memo book on the Council of the Six Nations held at Cattaraugus, Dec. 1-2, 1862 with the names and remarks of the attending chiefs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Permit to lease 6 acres of his improvement to Whites, signed by the "President" of a council of Tonawanda chiefs, and attested by Ely S. Parker, "Clerk." Freeman Guide 3370.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News item concerning a council at Tonawanda to bid farewell to Ely S. Parker who has joined Grant's army.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter about life with the 132nd Regt. N.Y. Infantry, stationed near Newbern, N.C. Newton asks to be remembered to relatives and friends and promises to dwell on other topics in a future letter which Martha can read "when all our little papooses are asleep." The letter is written in a hand unlike Newton Parker's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter acknowledging receipt of news from Carrie that William Parker is sick and not expected to recover, and advising Nic to move with his family to Tonawanda as Carrie "cannot take care of everything."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter from Chattanooga, with instructions about the division of his property should he be killed in the war. Ely writes before a battle between Grant and Bragg, and refers to his duties on the staffs of Generals J.E. Smith, Wm. F. Smith, and U.S. Grant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ely acknowledges Carrie's letter advising of William Parker's gradual recovery. He describes the country where his camp is located and the living standards of the people who occupy it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Part of a letter describing a battle fought Nov. 23 to 28, during which Lt. Towner of Batavia was wounded.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ely discusses his transfer in September from Gen. J.E. Smith's Division to Grant's staff, his own serious illness which has resulted in a loss of thirty pounds, a five day battle at Chattanooga, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Images note: A hand drawn map of the area around New Berne, with notations on verso concerning local place names and an encounter with the enemy on Feb. 1st to 3rd.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newton describes what happens to Union soldiers who are captured by the Rebels "either with a whole skin or in a wounded state." He closes by admitting he is not an "apt person to write an interesting...sensible letter."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note advising he has received telegram about Father's death, but could not reach home in time for funeral; written on verso of printed announcement of officers composing Grant's staff in the field.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: William Parker's obituary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newton asks for some mocassins as "our heavy government shoes are unbearable" in hot weather, also some summer socks and handkerchiefs. He would like to have two pudding sticks and two ladels as gifts for "two good families" who have been kind to him by relieving the monotony of army food. He closes by admitting he is not in a position "to make preemptory demands on our family resources, being, as you have intimated to me, of limited character."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Images note A group photograph of Grant and his staff, including Ely S. Parker, from the rotogravure section of the issue for May 30, 1920.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter deploring the lack of unity among the Indians. Ely blames Dr. Wilson for the rupture with Washington, resulting from the Indians' behavior during a visit from [Acting? Commissioner Mix. He advises Nic against having anything to do with a proposed delegation to Washington, pointing out that the country is bankrupt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brief letter giving highlights of a long talk with Commissioner Dole. The latter will not recognize the Chief government at Cattaraugus, is willing to treat with the New York Indians for their Kansas claims, and believes Rich is the strongest man for the New York agency.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from the New York Indian Agent stating that he has just received his commission and that he will be pleased to retain Nic as interpreter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Images note: Photograph at the time of his marriage. [cf. Parker, A.C. The life of General Ely S. Parker... Buffalo, 1919, p. 146]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request to be kept informed about any rumors at home connected with possible changes in the New York Indian Agency.

did.unittitle: ALS to Fred, Frank, Albert and Minnie Parker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A reply from Army Headquarters, Washington, to letters from Nic's children. Ely tells them about his work for General Grant, who will oppose Seymour in the presidential elections, and speaks of Grant's four children. He and Aunt Minnie expect to go north in two or three weeks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A "plan of operation" dealing with the advisability of waiting until the matter of title to the Indian lands has been settled by the New York Courts, before reviving in Washington the question of abrogation of the treaties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter commenting briefly on the Tonawanda census and advising that Sherman will be superseded by Ames as Indian Agent.

did.unittitle: ALS to Mrs. H. B. Griggs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter, written as Commissioner of Indian Affairs, stating that he is unable to secure a position in Washington for "Andrews, an invalid soldier."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A note from New York that he hopes to be at Cattaraugus on Wednesday with Minnie "provided the trains run."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter, which accompanied a copy of an Indian petition to prohibit sale of liquor to the Six Nations, which Marshall believes "may be of interest to your Temperance Division."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Report of Hon. E.S. Parker, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, to the Hon. Secretary of the Interior, on the communication of William Welsh, Esq., relative to the management of Indian Affairs." Pamphlet of five pages, published Washington, 1870 [!].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of resignation as Commissioner of Indian Affairs, to take effect Aug. 1, 1871, addressed to the President.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Investigation into Indian Affairs, before the Committee on Appropriations of the House of Representatives. Argument of N.P. Chipman, on behalf of Hon. E.S. Parker, Commissioner of Indian Affairs." Washington, 1871. 121 p.

did.unittitle: Civil War records of Seneca Indians

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pencilled data in leather bound notebook and on loose sheet, giving names, approximate ages, etc. of about 20 Seneca Indians, together with brief testimony concerning their participation in the War of 1812.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A reply, with which Ely enclosed a letter from the Commissioner concerning the New York Agent's interpreter, and advising that he plans to take Minnie out of school in May and send her to Nic for the summer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clipping headed "The Treaty of Suffalo Creek," outlining the facts connected with the claim of the New York Indians to a balance of 31,971,295 due them by the federal government.

did.unittitle: ALS to Caroline Parker Mt. Pleasant

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note sent with some newspaper clippings, stating that Minnie is getting along nicely and "will be walking in a week or so."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newspaper reprint of an exchange of letters regarding the authenticity of Red Jacket's remains to be reinterred by the Buffalo Historical Society.

did.unittitle: Address delivered upon reinterment of Red Jacket

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mutilated clipping from a Buffalo newspaper of an address delivered on the occasion of the reinterment of the remains of Red Jacket and other famous Indian chiefs, at Forest Lawn Cemetery, by the Buffalo Historical Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note that accompanied the return of a clipping, stating "General Grant is almost gone... I get full accounts from Fred."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newspaper reprint of a letter dealing with personal reminiscences of Ely S. Parker and of Ely's early estimate of Grant as "a most extraordinary man [who] will win a name and fame which has had no parallel in modern times."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter to one of Grant's schoolmates at Maysville, Ky., which criticizes articles by Badeau on Grant, dealing with the latter's forenames and other matters.

did.unittitle: ALS to Mrs. Harriet M. Converse

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter addressed to "Gayaneshaoh" with which was enclosed a list of Seneca words suitable as names for an "old man," "a rising young man," and a "promising young woman."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: According to A.C. Parker, "This manuscript is a portion of the Newhouse version of the Legend of Dekanwida and the founding of the League of the Iroquois, together with the rite of condolence." [For a photostat of a manuscript in the same hand, and a discussion of same by W. N. Fenton, see Film 345, and their Proceedings 93 (1949): 141-158.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter, advising that he has "little or no recollection of the matters revived by Genl. Wallace," and that Col. Rowley is dying in Chicago.

did.unittitle: Membership card, G.A.R., Reno Post, No. 44, Dept. of New York, New York City

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: General E. S. Parker's membership card.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note advising that a "horrid reptile" is being sent to her, apparently in fulfillment of a request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brief letter stressing the necessity for unity among the Indians in pressing their Kansas claims.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Images note: Photograph of Caroline, sister of Ely S. Parker and wife of John Mountpleasant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from a doctor stating that Ely Parker is suffering from diabetes and has been requested to call often "as a social patient, without charge."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An acknowledgment of a letter in which Ely states "The R.J. business looks encouraging, all owing to your perseverance and courage." He concludes with references to his poor health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newspaper clipping reporting the ceremony at Oshwaken, near Syracue, during which the adoption of Mrs. Harriet M. Converse by the Seneca in April was "confirmed by the governmental authority... of all the tribes composing the Iroquois Confederacy."

did.unittitle: ALS to Caroline G. Mt. Pleasant

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Power of attorney to receive "my proportionate share of all annuities."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of an address on the occasion of the unveiling of a monument dedicated by the New York Tammany Regiment to the memory of comrades killed in the Civil War. A prominent feature of the monument is a figure of the Delaware chief, Tammany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Obituary from an undated, unidentified newspaper, concerning Caroline Parker Mountpleasant who "died yesterday...aged about sixty years."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typewritten copy of an incomplete newspaper obituary of "Caroline Mountpleasant, often called the `Queen of the Tuscaroras,' who died on the 19th inst."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter concerning a power-of-attorney, authorizing his niece and her husband "to make such settlement in my name...as your good judgment may dictate" in the settlement of Caroline's estate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A copy in the handwriting of Ely S. Parker of a reply from the attorney for the administrators of John Mountpleasant's estats. Freeman Guide 3619.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter enclosing correspondence with lawyer [Pound] and asking his niece to pay the Akron undertaker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Power of attorney authorizing his niece to receive "my share of all annuities."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A signed typewritten reply to a request for a list of books on the Six Nations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter addressed to "my dear Snipe," and signed "The Wolf." Ely acknowledges two letters Mrs. Converse wrote to him while on a trip. He states "I do not feel well... I am very tired and care not how soon the end comes."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note addressed to "Dear Snipe" and signed "The Wolf" stating that a letter he has copied as requested is poorly written because of his ill health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Obituary of Ely S. Parker.

scopecontent.p: Obituary of Ely S. Parker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "In memoriam. Ely Samuel Parker, Brevet Brigadier-General, late U.S. Army, died at Fairfield, Conn., August 30th, 1895."

did.unittitle: Photograph of bust of Ely S. Parker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Images note: 2 black and white photographs of a bust made in 1895, shortly before Parker's death. The original is in the Rochester Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprint in the Columbus, O. "Masonic Chronicles," of an obituary article on Ely S. Parker, that originally appeared in the "Report of the Illinois Masonic Veteran Association." Lodge memberships, with dates of affiliation, are sketched. Images note: newspaper clipping photograph.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Incomplete clipping concerning Red Jacket relics offered for sale, including the medal presented to Red Jacket by Washington, and worn for many years by Ely S. Parker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newspaper notice of the reinterment of Ely S. Parker's remains by the Buffalo Historical Society in Forest Lawn Cemetery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clipping from the Buffalo Express, relating the prophetic `broken rainbow' vision of Elizabeth Parker before the birth of her son Ely.

did.unittitle: Title to the Seneca Indian Reservations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprint of an article, which appeared in the New York Sun under the caption "The Title to the Seneca Indian Reservations: The Courts' Answer to Judge Davie's Argument on H.R. Bill 12,270." The author refutes the Ogden Land Co.'s claims to the Cattaraugus and Allegany Reservations by citing treaties between the U.S. and Seneca Indians, and legal decisions rendered by the Courts of New York State.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Carbon copy of a typed petition, signed by a New York Indian, objecting to section 5 of H.R. 12,270, providing for the purchase of the Ogden Land Co.'s title to lands on the Cattaraugus, Allegany and Tuscarora Reservations.

did.unittitle: ALS to Editor of the San Diego Union

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter calling attention to inaccuracies in newspaper accounts of Ely S. Parker at the time of his death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typewritten copy of a letter, enclosing the list of corrections to the "League of the Iroquois" which Morgan made in his own copy and giving brief biographical facts on ALS to whom the book was dedicated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter to the Editor of the Buffalo Express from a classmate of Ely Parker's at Yates Academy.

scopecontent.p: Typewritten extract of an address on the occasion of the sesqui-centennial of St. Patrick's Lodge No. 4, Jamestown, suggesting similarities between Iroquois Long House and Masonic Lodge symbolism.

scopecontent.p: Recollections of a former resident of Batavia "now over 90 yrs." who knew Caroline and William Parker.

did.unittitle: Red Embers of the Long House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Red Embers of the Long House." (Three chapters of and unpublished manuscript, gleaned from letters in the Ely S. Parker Collection and other cited documents. Typewritten carbon copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprint of an address before the New York Historical Association, entitled "Buying Buffalo [city] from the Indians." The author deals with the activities of Herman B. Potter, Orlando Allen, James Stryker, Henry P. Wilcox, John F. Schermerhorn, Ransom H. Gillett, Nathaniel T. Strong and others connected with the Treaty of 1838, by means of which the Ogden Land Co. secured title to the Buffalo Creek Reservation. Bibliography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News item concerning a Council of the Six Nations, with a description of the Feather Dance, led by Edward Cornplanter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter dated May 27 from an engineer asking Ely "to send Turner to Mrs. Murray's for my large boots" which he would like to have sent on to him in Batavia.

scopecontent.p: Photostat of a [published?] poem.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An account of his experiences and the havoc and discouragement brought about by continual removals resulting from treaties and land sales.
